The rain over Walsall had a particular quality, a kind of weary persistence that didn't bother with the drama of a downpour but aimed instead for a slow, comprehensive soaking. It was a rain that seeped, that found the tiny imperfections in a window seal or the collar of a coat, and it had been DCI Eleanor Vance’s only companion for the last four hours. She sat in the driver's seat of the unmarked Ford, the engine cold, her breath a fleeting mist on the inside of the glass. The world beyond the windscreen was a palette of greys and damp browns; the corrugated iron of the industrial unit they were watching, the slick tarmac of the service road, the bruised sky.

"Anything?" DC Chopra's voice, startlingly young and crisp, crackled through the radio wedged in the cup holder.

Ellie picked it up, her thumb pressing the transmit button with an economy of movement that came from twenty-five years on the force. "Negative, Sameer. Just a very bored-looking pigeon and enough rain to float the Black Country out to sea. You?"

"Same, guv. Tea’s gone cold. The flask has betrayed me."

A ghost of a smile touched Ellie’s lips. Chopra was a good lad. Keen. A bit too much like a Labrador puppy sometimes, desperate for a pat on the head, but his paperwork was immaculate and he could actually make a comprehensible entry in the evidence log, which put him in the top percentile of DCs she’d had to break in. "Suffering builds character, Chopra. Stick with it."

She dropped the radio back into its holder and flexed her fingers around the steering wheel. A dull ache had settled deep in her right knee, a souvenir from a chase through a scrapyard in Tipton a decade ago. It was her body’s own weather forecast, and it was predicting a monsoon. She was fifty-two. Too old for this nonsense, for sitting in a damp car on a Tuesday night waiting for a low-level fence named Gazza to show up with a van full of stolen catalytic converters. This was a job for the keen puppies, not the old dog. But Superintendent Davies had made a point of it. "A personal touch, Ellie. Show the team you're still one of them. Boots on the ground." Davies's idea of 'boots on the ground' was sending someone else's boots to get damp while he attended a regional planning dinner.

She rubbed at her eyes, the heels of her palms pressing hard enough to make stars burst behind her lids. Fatigue was a constant, a low hum beneath the surface of her thoughts. When she pulled her hands away, she glanced at her knuckles, resting on the smooth grey plastic of the wheel. For a splinter of a second, the strangest thing happened. The texture of the dashboard, the faint crisscross pattern, was visible *through* her skin. It was as if her hand had become a pane of smoky glass. She blinked, hard. And it was gone. Her hand was just a hand again, solid and pale, the skin a little dry. A network of fine lines and a single, silvery scar from a misplaced bread knife.

A migraine aura, she told herself. Stress. Not enough sleep, too much caffeine. The optic nerve playing tricks. It had to be. She’d had them before, strange scintillating zig-zags at the edge of her vision. This was just a new, and admittedly unsettling, variation. She resolutely filed the incident away in the mental cabinet marked 'Things To Ignore' and forced her attention back to the shuttered door of Unit 14B.

Another hour crawled by. The pigeon, having concluded its business, flew away. Ellie’s mind drifted. It wasn't supposed to be like this. She’d pictured DCI as the pinnacle, a position of command and strategy, of moving pieces on a chessboard. She hadn't accounted for the sheer, grinding weight of the bureaucracy, the budget meetings, the performance reviews, the endless demand for statistics that painted a rosier picture than the reality on the streets. Her life had narrowed until the job was all that was left. It had consumed her marriage years ago, swallowed up friendships, and now it was gnawing away at her sanity, one stakeout at a time.

Her only escape, her one remaining secret pleasure, was the golf course. The early weekend mornings at the municipal, the clean crack of a well-hit drive, the singular focus on a small white ball. It was a different kind of problem-solving. Trajectory, wind speed, the lie of the land. There were rules, and they made sense. Unlike life. She had a set of second-hand Callaways in the boot of her own car, a battered stand bag she'd had since her thirties. It was the only part of her life that felt entirely her own, untainted by the job.

A flash of headlights jerked her back to the present. A white transit van, mud-splashed and dented, swung into the service road, its engine rattling like a can of bolts. It reversed clumsily up to the doors of Unit 14B.

"Contact," she said into the radio, her voice low and steady. The fatigue vanished, replaced by a familiar, cold thrill. "White transit. Stand by."

"Copied, guv," came Chopra's immediate reply, the puppy now a wolf, alert and ready.

The van's side door slid open and a man in a high-vis jacket jumped out. Gary "Gazza" Tomlinson. He was practically a local landmark. He fumbled with a set of keys, unlocked a huge padlock, and began to heave the big metal shutter upwards. It rose with a deafening screech that tore through the quiet evening. The moment it was high enough, two more figures emerged from the darkness of the unit.

"Right," Ellie murmured, her hand already on the door handle. "Let's go and say hello."

She gave the signal. Two other cars, hidden further down the road, flicked on their lights. Her own door opened and she was out in the rain, the cold shock of it welcome now. Chopra was already sprinting from his position, his longer legs eating up the ground. The three men by the van froze, their faces a comical tableau of surprise and dismay in the sudden glare of the headlights. Gazza, to his credit, reacted first. He spun around and bolted, not towards the road, but back into the labyrinthine mess of the industrial estate.

"Chopra, with me!" Ellie yelled, breaking into a surprisingly fast run, her bad knee screaming in protest. "Uniforms, secure the other two!"

Adrenaline was a wonderful anaesthetic. She ignored the pain, her eyes locked on Gazza’s bright yellow jacket as he dodged between stacked pallets and rusted skips. He was younger, but he was a smoker and she was fueled by pure, distilled rage at the thought of the paperwork this chase was going to generate. She was gaining on him. He glanced over his shoulder, his eyes wide with panic, and swerved into a narrow alley between two units. A dead end. He knew it the moment he was in. He spun around, panting, his hands held up.

"Alright, alright, guv! It's a fair cop!"

Ellie slowed to a walk, catching her breath, the rain plastering her hair to her forehead. Chopra arrived a second later, puffing but triumphant. "Got him, guv."

"Good work, Sameer. Cuff him." As Chopra wrestled with the cuffs and a suddenly uncooperative Gazza, Ellie leaned against the cold brick wall of the alley, the adrenaline starting to ebb, leaving the ache in her knee in its wake. She looked down at her hand, braced against the damp brickwork. And it happened again. Slower this time. A creeping transparency, starting at the fingertips. She could see the dark, moss-stained mortar of the wall through her own flesh. It was like watching ice melt, but in reverse, turning from solid to spectral. She stared, mesmerized and horrified, as the effect travelled up her wrist, her watch seeming to float on an invisible arm.

"Guv? You okay?" Chopra's voice cut through her daze.

She snatched her hand away from the wall, shoving it into her pocket. When she looked at it in the darkness there, it was solid again. Just a hand. "Fine," she snapped, her voice harsher than she intended. "Just... catching my breath. Get him back to the van." The rest of the arrest was a blur of procedure. The other two suspects were compliant, the van was full of stolen tech, and by the time they got back to the station, the canteen was serving lukewarm stew. Ellie skipped the stew. She went to her office, the strange flickering of her hand replaying in her mind. She wrote her initial report with a kind of numb efficiency, her fingers hitting the keyboard with mechanical precision. Davies would be pleased. A good result. A feather in his cap.

It was past midnight when she finally left the station. The rain had, at last, given up. The streets of Walsall glistened under the orange streetlights, empty and quiet. Her house was on a neat, boring estate that had seemed like a sensible choice ten years ago and now just felt like a trap. It was tidy, sterile. The home of someone who was never there. She kicked off her shoes, dropped her keys in a ceramic bowl by the door, and walked through the silent house to the downstairs bathroom.

She didn't know why, but she had to look. A morbid curiosity. She flicked on the light. The face in the mirror was tired. Dark circles under the eyes, a fretful line between her brows. The face of DCI Eleanor Vance, fifty-two, divorced, no kids, married to the job. It was a face she was tired of looking at. She sighed, picked up her toothbrush, and squeezed a line of paste onto it. She turned on the tap, ran the brush under it, and began to scrub at her teeth with a grim determination. It was just another night. Another day done.

She spat into the sink, rinsed her mouth, and looked up.

And screamed. A silent, strangled gasp that caught in her throat.

The mirror was empty.

No, not empty. The mirror was reflecting the bathroom perfectly. The beige tiles, the towel rail with its neatly folded hand towel, the bottle of hand soap on the edge of the sink, the light fixture on the ceiling. It was all there. Everything except her.

Her mind refused to process it. She could feel her heart hammering against ribs she couldn't see. She could feel the cold tile floor under feet that were not there. The toothbrush, which she had been holding, fell from an invisible hand, clattering against the white porcelain of the basin with a sound that was far too loud in the sudden, terrifying silence of her world. She raised her arms, or where her arms ought to be. Nothing. She flapped them, a frantic, desperate motion. All she saw was the wall behind her. She was gone. The face she was so tired of looking at, the body that ached with the weight of her life, the whole solid presence of her, had simply... ceased to be. There was only the empty space where a woman should have been, and the frantic, invisible pulse of pure, unadulterated terror.Her first rational thought, slicing through the static of her terror, was that she was having a stroke. Or a complete psychotic break. The mind, pushed far enough, would simply snap the tether to reality. She had seen it happen to suspects, to victims, even to a colleague once after a particularly gruesome case involving a family. But this felt different. It didn't feel like a hallucination. The chill of the tiled floor was real, the lingering minty tang of toothpaste in her mouth was real, the solid, familiar shape of her own jaw beneath her questing, invisible fingers was terrifyingly, irrefutably real. She could feel the soft fabric of her Henley shirt against her skin, trace the waistband of her trousers, feel the pulse hammering in a throat she could no longer see.

It was then she looked down. Her clothes weren’t invisible. They hung in the air, a ghostly sculpture of a person. The grey shirt was rumpled, the dark trousers creased at the non-existent knees, the sleeves puckered at the elbows. It was the most obscene thing she had ever seen; a person-shaped void, delineated by cotton and denim. She held up an arm, and the grey sleeve lifted with it, empty and limp from the wrist. She balled a fist she could not see, and the material at the end of the sleeve tightened. It was a macabre puppet show, and she was the unseen puppeteer, the ghost in her own machine.

The detective in her, buried under an avalanche of panic, began to claw its way out. Observation. Facts. What did she know? Fact one: her body was invisible to the naked eye, and apparently to mirrors. Fact two: her clothes were not. Fact three: she was still solid, possessed mass, and was subject to gravity. Fact four: the phenomenon was intermittent before, but now seemed total. She stumbled out of the bathroom, away from the damning evidence of the mirror, her hand trailing along the wall for balance. The sensation was bizarre, watching the wall and feeling its textured wallpaper slide against a palm that wasn't there. She was a moving blind spot.

She made her way into the living room, the familiar space now alien and menacing. Every object seemed to mock her with its stolid visibility. The sofa, the television, the framed photograph on the mantelpiece of her and her ex-husband, taken in a happier time. She was a ghost in her own home, a ghost in her own life. Who could she call? The very idea was insane. ‘Hello, desk sergeant? I’d like to report a missing DCI. Yes, that’s me. I’m reporting myself missing. I’m at my home address, but I appear to have mislaid my entire physical body.’ They would have the mental health team at her door in ten minutes. Dr. Evans? He’d triple her antidepressants and book her a long stay in a quiet room with padded walls. Chopra? The poor lad would have a nervous breakdown. No. This was hers. A problem of one. The ultimate solitary confinement.

Her gaze fell on the hallway that led to the back door and the small, attached garage. In there, propped against a stack of old newspapers, was her golf bag. The battered Callaways, the scuffed leather of the bag itself. Suddenly, she had a desperate, irrational need to see it, to touch it. It was her only anchor, the one part of her life that was just about sport and physics and clean air, untainted by crime and paperwork and the slow, grinding erosion of her soul. Moving with a new, frantic purpose, she walked towards the garage, her empty clothes shuffling through the silent house. It was an absurd pilgrimage, a search for solace in a set of metal sticks. But in a world that had just casually ripped up every rule she had ever known, the simple, solid reality of a three-iron felt like the only sane thing left.The internal door to the garage clicked open with a familiar groan, pushed by a disembodied grey sleeve. The air inside was cool and still, thick with the scents of engine oil, damp concrete, and the faint, sweet perfume of dried grass clippings from the lawnmower. It was a space of deferred tasks and forgotten hobbies; stacked boxes of case files marked for archiving, a dusty workbench cluttered with tools she rarely used, a deflated bicycle tyre hanging from a hook like a dead snake. But her eyes sought only one thing. Propped in the corner, illuminated by the weak light spilling from the hallway, was her golf bag. It was old and worn, the black and red fabric faded, the stand slightly bent. It looked solid. It looked real.

She approached it slowly, a shuffling set of clothes moving through the gloom. Her invisible hand reached out, the grey cuff of her shirt hovering just above the worn leather of the bag’s handle. She hesitated for a fraction of a second, then her fingers closed around it. The feel of it was a shock of normality. The pebbled texture of the handle, the slight give in the stitching, the sheer physical fact of it beneath her grasp. It was an anchor in a world that had become a phantom sea. She let out a breath she hadn’t realised she was holding, her shoulders, hidden beneath the fabric, slumping in relief. She ran her other hand down the side of the bag, her unseen fingers tracing the zips and pockets, finally closing around the cold, hard shaft of her driver where it stuck out from the top. The sensation was grounding, a confirmation that her sense of touch, at least, had not deserted her.

The terror, while not gone, receded enough for the investigator to surface. This was a scene. She was the evidence. She had to analyse it. The toothbrush had been visible when it fell. The clothes were visible now. The golf club in her hand was still stubbornly, reassuringly a golf club. She pulled her seven-iron from its slot, the metal scraping softly against the other clubs. Holding it aloft, she watched as the club hovered in the garage air, suspended by an unseen force. It was a cheap magic trick, utterly baffling and real. Any object she held remained visible. This wasn’t a field of invisibility that extended outwards; it was a property of her own body. The implications started to slot into place with cold, logical precision. She couldn't walk down the street. People wouldn't see her, but they would see a floating coat and trousers ambling along the pavement. She couldn't pick up a cup of coffee without it appearing to levitate.

There was only one logical, if utterly mad, course of action. The clothes had to come off. The thought made her skin, the skin she could feel but not see, crawl. To be naked and invisible in her own cold garage felt like the punchline to a terrible joke she didn't understand. With clumsy, fumbling motions, she began to undress. Unbuttoning her shirt was a bizarre act of faith, her fingers working by memory and feel alone, the fabric parting to reveal… nothing. Just the back wall of the garage seen through the gap in her shirt. She pulled it off, letting it drop to the concrete floor where it lay in a sad, grey heap. Then came the trousers, the belt buckle cold against her spectral fingertips, until they too were pooled around her ankles. She stepped out of them, and then, finally, stripped off her socks and underwear.

She stood for a long moment in the absolute, bone-aching cold of the garage, every nerve ending screaming with the chill. She was completely, utterly gone. She waved an arm and saw only the dusty workbench behind it. She looked down at the floor and saw only the cracked concrete where her feet should be. The only proof of her existence was the cold, the frantic drumming of her own heart, and the faint disturbance in the air as she breathed. She took a tentative step, then another. It felt like walking in a dream, a disembodied consciousness drifting through a solid world. She shuffled over to the wing mirror of her car, leaning in close until her non-existent nose was almost touching the glass. The reflection was perfect and unbroken: the shelves, the boxes, the sad, discarded pile of her clothes on the floor. Of Eleanor Vance, there was not a single trace. The experiment was a success. The conclusion was horrifying. This was not an illusion. This was her reality now. A ghost in her own life, stripped bare and shivering in the dark.## Chapter 2

The cold was the first thing to truly cut through the panic. Not the background chill of the rainy evening, but a deep, invasive cold that settled into her unseen bones as she stood naked on the concrete floor. It was a physical fact, an undeniable sensation that proved her body, though vanished from sight, was still a vessel of nerve endings and shivering muscle. The ghost was getting hypothermia. The absurdity of it was almost enough to make her laugh, but the sound died in her throat. She had to move, to get warm, to think. She turned, a ripple of disturbed air in the stillness of the garage, and walked back into the house, her invisible feet silent on the laminate flooring of the hall. She closed the door to the garage behind her, the soft click of the latch sealing her in with her impossible secret.

A hot shower seemed like the most logical first step. It was a routine, a human ritual, and she clung to the idea of it like a drowning woman to a piece of driftwood. The bathroom was a chamber of horrors now, with its truth-telling mirror, but she forced herself back inside. She didn't look at the reflection of the empty room. Instead, she reached for the shower dial, her unseen fingers recognising the familiar shape and resistance. Watching the chrome fixture turn, seemingly of its own accord, was profoundly unsettling. She stepped into the cubicle and pulled the glass door shut. When the water hit, hot and hard, she gasped. It wasn't just the warmth, it was the confirmation. She could feel every single drop, a million tiny impacts against her shoulders, her back, her legs. The steam billowed around her, swirling and eddying against an invisible shape, momentarily outlining a human form before dissipating into the general haze. It was the closest she had come to seeing herself in what felt like an eternity.

Wrapped in a large bath towel that seemed to float around her middle, she padded into the living room and sank into the soft cushions of her armchair. The fabric dipped, compressed by a weight it could not see. She sat there for a long time, the only sound the frantic thumping of her own heart and the drip of water from her spectral hair onto the towel. The detective in her began to stir, methodically, pushing aside the raw animal fear. This was a case. The most bizarre case of her career, and she was the sole victim, witness, and investigator. She began to assemble the facts in her head. Fact one: the condition is total invisibility of her biological matter. Fact two: inanimate objects she holds or wears remain visible. Fact three: her physical solidity, mass, and sensory perceptions remain intact. She could still feel, hear, taste, smell, and interact with the world. She was a perfectly functional human being who had been deleted from the visible spectrum. The ‘migraine aura’ theory was now laughably insufficient. This wasn't a trick of the light; it was a fundamental violation of the laws of physics as she knew them.

As dawn began to bleed grey light through the cracks in the blinds, the silence of the house was shattered by a shrill, demanding ring. The landline. Her heart, which had just begun to settle into a steady rhythm of dread, kicked into a frantic gallop. The caller ID display glowed on the handset in the hallway: WEST MIDS POLICE. They were checking on her. She was late. Of course she was late. For the first time in twenty-five years, DCI Vance was a no-show. The phone rang again, insistent. It was a lifeline to a world she was no longer part of, and a threat to the secret she had to keep. She had to answer it. To not answer would trigger a welfare check, and the thought of a pair of uniformed officers breaking down her door to find an empty house with a pile of clothes in the garage was unthinkable.

Taking a deep, steadying breath that did nothing to calm her, she walked to the hallway table. Her invisible hand reached out and picked up the receiver, which then floated eerily in the air. "Vance," she said, and was shocked by how normal her voice sounded.
"Guv? It's Sameer. You okay? You're never late." Chopra. Of course. His voice was a mixture of surprise and genuine concern.
"Chopra," she rasped, deliberately roughening her voice, making it sound clogged and sick. "Yeah. Sorry. Woke up feeling like I'd been run over by a bus. Some kind of bug. Stomach, head… the works." It was her first lie. The first stone laid in the foundation of her new, hidden existence.
"Oh, right. Blimey. Is it that thing that's been going around? Half of admin are off with it. Do you need anything? I can drop off some supplies after my shift." The puppy, loyal to the last. The kindness was a knife in her gut.
"No," she said, too quickly. "No, don't. It's… explosive. Trust me, you want to maintain a five-mile exclusion zone. I'm going to turn my phone off and try to sleep it off. I'll check in tomorrow."
"Okay, guv. Hope you feel better soon. Davies is going to be chuffed about the Gazza arrest, by the way. The Super's already emailed about it."
"Good," she croaked. "That's good." She hung up, placing the handset back on its cradle with a hand that trembled invisibly. The receiver settled into place, and the connection to her old life was severed.

She had done it. She had bought herself time. A day, maybe two. The relief was a thin, brittle skin over a vast emptiness. She slid down the wall, her towel-wrapped form slumping to the floor in a way that would have looked utterly bizarre to an observer. The job. Davies, Chopra, the Gazza arrest. It all felt like it had happened to someone else, in another lifetime. Her entire career, her identity, was built on presence, on being seen. On the authority she projected when she walked into an interview room, the reassuring glance she could give a victim, the intimidating stare that could break a suspect. All of it, gone. She couldn’t walk into her office, couldn’t chair a briefing, couldn’t testify in court. DCI Eleanor Vance, as the world knew her, had ceased to exist. The job that had consumed everything else in her life was now the one thing that was utterly, completely impossible for her to do.

And then, a thought, insidious and strange, surfaced through the mire of her despair. She looked at the mantelpiece, at the photo of her and Graham, smiling on a beach in Cornwall. She thought of the endless meetings, the budget cuts, the stifling bureaucracy. She thought of Davies and his political games, of the weary ache in her bones after a thankless sixteen-hour day. All of that was gone, too. The constant pressure to be DCI Vance, the unblinking eye of the force, the woman who had sacrificed everything for the job. She was free from it. Not just from the duties, but from the scrutiny. No one was watching her anymore. No one *could* watch her. It was a horrifying, terrifying, and profoundly lonely kind of freedom. The freedom of a ghost, adrift in her own life, with no rules and no one to answer to. Shivering there on the floor, a disembodied consciousness draped in a bath towel, Ellie Vance began to wonder if her life had just ended, or if it had, in some terrible and incomprehensible way, just begun.The thought of freedom was a dangerous, seductive whisper in the roaring silence of her mind. For twenty-five years, she had been a public servant in the most literal sense; her face known to every villain and beat cop in the Black Country, her life forfeit to the relentless demands of the job. Now, she was the ultimate private citizen. More than private. She was a secret. The idea was so potent it was almost physically painful. She could walk anywhere, go anywhere, listen to anything. She was the perfect surveillance machine. The ultimate undercover officer. The thought was immediately followed by a wave of self-loathing. Was that really her first instinct? To weaponise her own affliction for the job that had already taken everything from her? The irony was so bitter it tasted like bile.

Slowly, she got to her feet, the towel clutched around her waist. The house was cold and her stomach was a tight knot of hunger and anxiety. Food. She needed food. The journey to the kitchen was an exercise in navigating by memory and touch alone. She ran an invisible hand along the cool surface of the kitchen counter, her fingers finding the handle of the fridge. Inside, the light flickered on, illuminating the contents. A half-empty bottle of milk, some wilting lettuce, a sad-looking block of cheddar. It looked like the fridge of a person who didn’t live here. She reached for the milk, her brain calculating the position of her hand with unnerving accuracy. The bottle lifted, suspended in the air, and she carried it to the counter, her movements slow and deliberate, like a bomb disposal expert.

Making a simple cup of tea and a cheese sandwich became the most complex and mentally taxing operation of her life. She had to trust her proprioception, the body’s innate sense of its position in space, to a degree she had never imagined. She found a mug by touch, placed a teabag in it by faith, and held it under the kettle’s spout, praying she had the angle right. The click of the boiling kettle was a gunshot in the quiet room. Pouring the water was terrifying; she had to rely entirely on the sound of the filling mug and the increasing weight in her unseen hand. She ended up with scalding water splashed across her spectral knuckles, the pain a sharp, welcome confirmation of her own reality. The sandwich was a similar ordeal. The knife floated, slicing through the cheese. The bread seemed to butter itself. She ate standing by the counter, forcing down the dry bread and tasteless cheese, acutely aware that she couldn't see her own mouth, couldn't watch her own hands. It was the loneliest meal she had ever eaten.

After the ghost of a breakfast, she made her way to the small study. Her laptop sat on the desk, closed. Here was a window. A way to reach out into the world without being seen, a tool she already used to exist at a distance. She sat down, the office chair sighing under her weight, and opened the screen. Her fingers, guided by decades of muscle memory, found the home keys on the keyboard. She opened a browser, the screen’s light bathing a patch of empty air. For a moment she just stared at the search bar, the blinking cursor a tiny, rhythmic pulse of infinite possibility and utter hopelessness. What could she possibly type?

‘Human body becomes transparent’. ‘Spontaneous invisibility’. ‘Sudden cellular translucency’. The search results were a predictable cascade of science fiction tropes, crank medical theories from the dark corners of the internet, and forum posts from people who believed they could astral project. There was nothing scientific, nothing medical, nothing real. She spent an hour diving down rabbit holes, reading about quantum entanglement, military cloaking technology, and obscure neurological conditions that affected self-perception, but none of them fit. They were disorders of the mind, not the flesh. Her mind was horribly, terrifyingly lucid. It was her body that had staged the coup. The silence from the legitimate world was deafening. There were no case studies, no research papers, no bewildered articles in medical journals. Whatever this was, it was happening to her and her alone. She was a medical anomaly of one.

The sound of the letterbox clattering shut made her jump so violently the chair squeaked. Footsteps crunched on the gravel path outside, then receded down the street. The post. A bill, a takeaway menu, a circular. A dispatch from a world that was still running on time, a world where people were visible and paid their gas bills and ordered pizza. She crept to the front door and peered through the spyhole. The street was empty save for a neighbour from three doors down, wrestling his recycling bin to the kerb. He paused to stretch his back, wincing, utterly oblivious to the invisible woman watching him from behind the door. The sheer, unbridgeable chasm between their two realities was dizzying. He had a bad back. She had no body. They were living in different universes, separated by a pane of glass and a few feet of air.

She sank to the floor again, the sheer weight of her solitude pressing down on her. The house, once a sterile sanctuary from the chaos of her job, had become a prison. She was trapped. She could order groceries online, she supposed, have them left on the doorstep. She could live here, in the quiet and the dark, a ghost haunting the rooms of her own life, until her money ran out or her mind finally fractured. But as she sat there, her gaze drifted towards the hallway, towards the closed door of the garage. Behind it, leaning in the corner, was her golf bag. The thought of the golf course, the wide open green under a vast sky, was a sudden, desperate craving. The clean, uncomplicated physics of it. Out there, in the dark, her invisibility wouldn't be a curse. It would be an advantage. No one would see the odd-looking woman practicing her swing at two in the morning. No one would see her at all. The idea took root, a small, defiant weed pushing up through the concrete of her despair. She couldn't be DCI Vance. She couldn't even be Ellie Vance. But maybe, just maybe, she could be a golfer.## Chapter 3

The day was the longest of her life. A sentence served in ten-hour increments, measured by the slow march of sunlight across the living room carpet. She was a phantom in a diorama of her own life, watching the world through glass. She saw her neighbour’s children leave for school, their shouts and laughter like sounds from another planet. She saw an Amazon delivery van pull up, the driver jogging to the door opposite with a parcel, his movements full of a casual, unthinking visibility that she now envied with a burning intensity. She did not turn on the television or the radio. The thought of hearing about the world—about crimes, about politics, about the weather over Walsall—felt like listening to a report from a country from which she had been permanently exiled. The silence was a presence, broken only by the hum of the fridge and the frantic, looping monologue in her own head.

As dusk began to blur the edges of the day, the passive agony of waiting solidified into a hard, cold resolve. The golf course. The thought had become an obsession, a focal point in the swirling chaos of her new reality. It was no longer about solace; it was about action. A test. An experiment to see if she could function in this new state, or if she was doomed to haunt the two floors of her semi-detached house until she went mad. A plan, police-like in its pragmatism, began to form. She couldn't carry the clubs; the sight of a floating golf bag trotting down the street would guarantee a call to every news outlet in the country. Alistair placed the bag of tools on a clear section of workbench, the canvas seeming to settle itself. The immediate crisis was over, the retreat successful. But the parasite was still there, a low, hungry hum in their minds, a reminder that defence was not enough. They had been reactive for too long. It was time to go on the offensive. "Alistair," Ellie said, turning from her inspection of a rack of tiny, gleaming screwdrivers. Her voice was quiet, but it held the hard, unmistakable edge of a DCI giving a briefing. "The hearth was our training exercise. Now the real work begins. We can't just keep building things. We need more data. We need to understand the enemy. Your case file, the Coventry traffic cop… there are others out there like us. We need to find another one. Not just to build a bigger wall. We need to find them so we can learn how this thing works, and how to kill it."## Chapter 10

Alistair looked at the empty space where Ellie stood, his head tilted as if trying to bring an invisible object into focus. Her declaration to "kill it" was the most terrifying and exhilarating thing he had heard in his eighteen months of solitude. His entire existence had been a quiet, managed retreat, a rear-guard action against the encroaching fog. The idea of turning around and charging headlong into that fog, seeking out its very source, was anathema to his cautious, ordered nature. And yet, the logic was as clean and inescapable as the mechanism of a fine chronometer. Defence was a losing game. An army of two had a better chance than an army of one. The watchmaker, who had spent a lifetime making things run, finally saw the sense in not just winding his own clock, but in seeking out others that had stopped.

"Then this is no longer a workshop," he said, his voice quiet but resolute. He gestured with an unseen hand to the pristine benches and gleaming tools. "It is an incident room." The words felt strange and momentous in the small, quiet space. His sanctuary, the last bastion of his private, ordered world, had been requisitioned for a war he had only just realised he was fighting. It felt like a violation, but also, strangely, like a promotion. He was no longer a hermit, hiding from the world. He was now quartermaster and chief analyst for a special investigations unit of two.

The transformation of the space began immediately. They brought in a small table and a chair from his kitchen, setting up a dedicated workstation for Ellie's laptop opposite his own workbench. The juxtaposition was striking: on one side, the intricate, analogue world of brass gears and polished steel; on the other, the glowing, digital portal into the vast, interconnected data-sphere of the modern world. An invisible woman sat at the table, her fingers a blur over the keyboard, the screen's light illuminating a patch of empty air. An invisible man sat at the workbench, a tiny jeweler's loupe floating near his eye as he methodically disassembled the pocket watch, the tiny, repetitive actions a form of meditation, a way to keep his own focus sharp while Ellie hunted in the electronic wilderness. They worked in a shared, purposeful silence, the soft click of Ellie’s keyboard a counterpoint to the delicate tick and scrape of Alistair’s tools.

Ellie’s approach was different this time, honed by the new, terrifying clarity of their situation. She was no longer looking for anomalies. She was profiling for a specific vulnerability. She built a complex search algorithm in her head, a DCI's intuitive leap translated into database queries. She cross-referenced unresolved, low-level incident reports—reports marked 'NFAR' that had a hint of the inexplicable—with a new set of data: public records of profound personal and professional loss. She trawled digital archives of bankruptcy filings, linking them to sudden spikes in erratic driving reports. She scanned obituaries and divorce records from the preceding months of 'phantom burglaries' where nothing of value was taken. It was a grim, voyeuristic trawl through the wreckage of other people's lives, but she did it with the detached focus of a surgeon. She was not looking for criminals. She was looking for casualties.

After hours of methodical searching, she returned to their strongest lead: the Coventry traffic cop's report. The driver of the swerving car. Marcus Thorne. Forty-eight years old. A HGV driver with a twenty-five-year clean record. The original incident report dismissed him as a probable drunk driver who had simply gotten lucky with the breathalyzer. But Ellie bypassed the summary and went straight for the source data, pulling up the digital file on Thorne himself. And there it was. Three months before the swerving incident, 'Thorne Haulage Ltd,' a family business started by his grandfather, had gone into liquidation. Thorne had lost everything: his company, his fleet of trucks, his professional identity. He had gone from being the boss to just another unemployed driver looking for agency work. The hollowing out had been swift and brutal.

"I have him, Alistair," Ellie said, her voice cutting through the quiet of the workshop. Alistair carefully placed a microscopic gear onto his velvet mat and turned his unseen face towards her. "The driver. Marcus Thorne. His company went under. He lost a lifetime's work, his family's legacy. The traffic cop said Thorne was disoriented, argumentative. He claimed the steering had 'gone funny,' that the lorry had 'jumped.' The cop thought he was making excuses. But what if he wasn't? What if he was fading, right there in the cab, doing sixty miles an hour on the M6? What if the lorry 'jumped' because for a split second, its driver ceased to fully exist?"

The theory was horrifying, but it slotted into their understanding of the phenomenon with a sickening click. Thorne wasn't swerving to avoid something unseen. He *was* the unseen thing. His intermittent physical state was causing the vehicle to behave erratically. He was a danger not just to himself, but to everyone around him. The cold spot inside Ellie’s head seemed to pulse in grim recognition. This was not a passive, gentle fading. It could be violent. It could be catastrophic.

She drilled deeper, her fingers flying across the keys. A current address for Thorne in a tired suburb of Rugby. A flag on his file for two subsequent 'public order' disturbances, both minor, both involving arguments in public where witnesses claimed he seemed to be "shouting at no one." He was deteriorating. He was losing control. He was shedding the routines that kept him anchored faster than either she or Alistair had. They had their next target. "Rugby," she announced, the single word a new destination, a new mission objective. "He's in Rugby. And from the look of these reports, he's coming apart at the seams. We need to get to him. Not just to find answers. We need to get to him before he hurts someone. Or before he disappears for good."The transformation of the workshop was absolute. Alistair, a man who had not moved a single tool from its designated hook in twenty years, now surveyed a large-scale Ordnance Survey map of the Midlands spread across his main workbench, held down at the corners by heavy brass paperweights. His collection of priceless, half-repaired timepieces had been carefully moved to a side bench, their intricate mechanisms now secondary to the more urgent mechanics of their mission. His sanctuary had become an incident room, and he had, with a quiet and surprising alacrity, become its chief intelligence analyst, his meticulous mind perfectly suited to the new task of route-planning and logistical support. Ellie, for her part, had established her digital command post, the laptop a humming portal from which she launched sorties into the data trails of their new target, her focus as intense and all-consuming as any major investigation she had ever run.

Their new partnership was a study in contrasts. Alistair, grounded in the analogue world of maps and mechanics, planned their physical journey. He traced the route from Solihull to Rugby on the paper map with an unseen finger, his voice a low murmur as he calculated fuel consumption for the Morris Minor and identified potential blackspots for surveillance. He was methodical, cautious, pointing out the vulnerabilities of taking such a conspicuous, vintage car on a long journey. Ellie, operating in the abstract realm of data, was more aggressive. She saw the risks, but her focus was on the target, the urgent need to intercept Thorne before his deteriorating state caused a catastrophe.

"The car is a risk, Eleanor," Alistair stated, his disembodied voice emanating from beside the map. "On the motorway, it is an anomaly. It draws the eye. If we were to be stopped for any reason, a routine check… the consequences are unthinkable. And I must confess, I have not taken her on a journey of more than twenty miles in over a decade. Her reliability is, at this point, a theoretical concept."

"It’s the only asset we have," Ellie countered, her eyes not leaving the screen where Marcus Thorne’s digital ghost was taking shape. "We move at night. We stick to the back roads where we can. The risk of the journey is high, but the risk of leaving a volatile, intermittently invisible HGV driver to his own devices is higher. He's a ticking bomb, Alistair. We have to get there." Her logic was brutal and unassailable, the cold calculus of command. Alistair fell silent, conceding the point. The mission parameters were set by the threat, not by their comfort. They would take the Morris Minor.

They left under the cloak of a moonless night, the little green car a whisper of motion through the sleeping towns of the Midlands. The journey was a long, ninety-minute ordeal of sustained, silent tension. Every pair of headlights in the rear-view mirror was a potential threat, every distant siren a possible end to their impossible enterprise. Ellie navigated, her voice a low, steady presence in the dark, while Alistair drove with a focus so absolute it was a physical force in the small cabin. They were a ghost crew sailing a ghost ship through a world that could not be allowed to see them. As they drove, Alistair, perhaps needing to fill the tense silence, began to talk about the car, about his father teaching him to drive in it, about the faded scent of his mother’s perfume that he could still sometimes smell in the woollen seat covers. It was not a lament for the past, Ellie realised, but a quiet statement of what he was fighting to protect. He was not just saving himself; he was saving the library of memories that made him who he was.

They arrived in Rugby in the dead hour before dawn, the town’s industrial estates and tired-looking housing developments a world away from the manicured lawns of Solihull. The address they had for Thorne was a flat in a grim, four-storey block, its concrete facade stained with damp, its balconies cluttered with rusting satellite dishes and broken furniture. The place radiated a palpable air of neglect and quiet desperation. There was no empty house opposite, no convenient observation post. Their operational theatre had become infinitely more complex and exposed. They parked the Morris at the end of the road, half-hidden in the shadow of a large, graffiti-covered telecoms cabinet, and began their wait.

For hours, nothing. The block of flats remained dormant. But as the sun rose, bringing with it the daily churn of people leaving for work and school, they got their first sign. A window on the third floor, which Ellie had identified as Thorne’s, slid open with a screech. A moment later, a half-eaten pork pie, trailing a greasy slick of jelly, arced through the air and splattered on the pavement below. It was followed by a torrent of furious, disembodied swearing that echoed across the car park, a litany of curses aimed at the world in general. A woman walking her dog hurried past, pulling her pet away from the mess on the ground and casting a nervous glance up at the open window from which the abuse seemed to be emanating. Alistair let out a soft, appalled gasp. His own invisibility had been a quiet, sad affair of floating teacups and self-dusting furniture. This was different. This was aggressive, chaotic, and public. This was a man not just fading, but actively lashing out at the world as he went. Their ticking bomb was live.The greasy splatter of the pork pie on the pavement was a punctuation mark at the end of a sentence Ellie hadn't wanted to read. It was a declaration of chaos, a public tantrum thrown by a man whose internal world was collapsing so violently it was spilling out into the open. Beside her, she felt Alistair recoil, a subtle shift in the air that spoke of profound dismay. His own affliction was a quiet, mannered affair, a secret kept with the same neat precision as his workshop. This raw, aggressive display of psychic collapse was a brutal confirmation that their condition was not uniform; it was a bespoke malady that preyed on the unique weaknesses of its host. For Alistair, the parasite fed on quiet grief. For Ellie, it had fed on hollowed-out duty. For Marcus Thorne, it was clearly feasting on pure, undirected rage.

"We cannot approach him like we approached each other," Ellie said, her voice a low, hard whisper that cut through the vintage car’s quiet interior. The DCI had taken full command, the shock giving way to a cold, tactical assessment. "A note will be a provocation. A direct approach, even an invisible one, could be met with violence. His anchor isn't a quiet memory of a loved one; it's a burning grievance against the world. He's not hiding from his condition; he's weaponising it." She looked at the grimy facade of the block of flats, a vertical slum radiating misery. "I need to get inside. I need to get a baseline reading on his environment and his routine. You stay with the car, Alistair. You are our transport and our only way out. Keep the engine warm. If you see police, you leave. Do you understand? You do not wait for me. You leave." The order was brutal, the protocol of a deep-cover operation where one partner might have to be sacrificed for the mission to survive. Alistair did not reply, but the slight dip of the driver's seat was his silent, grim assent.

Her opportunity came twenty minutes later. A harried-looking young woman, wrestling with a buggy and two shopping bags, struggled to open the main entrance door to the block. Ellie slipped through the gap behind her, a ghost riding in the wake of another person’s daily struggle. The inside of the building was even more depressing than the outside. The air was thick with the smell of stale cooking, damp, and cheap air freshener failing to mask something vaguely unpleasant. Muffled sounds bled through the thin walls: the tinny beat of daytime television, the sharp, angry words of an argument, the desolate sound of a baby crying without hope of being comforted. This was a place where lives were lived on top of one another, a petri dish of quiet desperation. Ellie took the stairs, her trainers silent on the worn, stained carpet, her invisible hand gliding along a sticky banister. She was an unseen trespasser in a building full of people who already felt invisible in their own ways.

She found Thorne’s flat, 3C, at the end of a dimly lit corridor. She pressed her unseen ear to the cheap wood of the door. From inside, she could hear a television blaring a mind-numbing quiz show, the questions and meaningless applause a stark contrast to the aggressive silence behind it. And then she heard another sound, a rhythmic, violent thud. Thud. Thud. Thud. It was the sound of a man repeatedly, methodically, punching a wall. Each impact was followed by a low, guttural grunt of effort and pain. He wasn't just angry. He was trying to feel something, anything, through the fog of his own dissolution, battling his invisibility with the brute, physical reality of pain. Ellie stepped back from the door, her own invisible skin crawling. This was worse than she had imagined. Alistair was trying to remember. She was trying to build. Marcus Thorne was just trying to break things, starting with himself.

She had been waiting for almost an hour, concealed in the dark recess at the end of the corridor, when the door to 3C was wrenched open. Marcus Thorne stood silhouetted in the doorway for a moment, and Ellie finally saw her target in the flesh. He was a big man, running to seed, his large frame stooped inside a stained tracksuit. His face was blotchy and pale, his eyes sunk deep in bruised-looking sockets, burning with a restless, frantic anger. His knuckles were raw and bleeding. He looked like a bear with a thorn in its paw, enraged by a pain it could neither see nor understand. He slammed the door behind him, the flimsy frame shuddering in protest, and stomped off down the corridor towards the stairs, his heavy footsteps echoing his fury. This was Ellie's chance. It was a huge risk, but the intelligence to be gained from inside his flat was too valuable to pass up. As Thorne’s footsteps receded, she slipped forward. She had no tools, but she didn’t need them. He hadn’t even bothered to lock the door. With a soft click, she pushed it open and slipped into the lion's den.

The flat was a disaster zone, a perfect reflection of the chaos in its owner’s mind. The air was thick with the smell of stale beer, unwashed clothes, and greasy takeaways. Empty pizza boxes and beer cans littered every surface. An overflowing ashtray sat perilously on the arm of a sofa that had seen better decades. In the centre of the living room wall was a ragged area of exposed plasterboard, the target of Thorne’s desperate, self-harming assault. It was a scene of total collapse, the habitat of a man who had given up on every facet of a normal life. But amidst the squalor, on a small, dust-free shelf high on the wall, sat a single, pristine object. It was a beautiful, exquisitely detailed scale model of a Scania R-series truck, painted in the smart green and gold livery of 'Thorne Haulage Ltd'. It was his anchor. His last, treasured memory of a life of purpose, a life where his name meant something, a life he could see and touch.

Drawn by an investigator's instinct, Ellie moved towards the model truck. It was his version of Alistair's clocks, her golf clubs. This was the nexus of his loss. As she got closer, she saw that propped against the front wheel of the model was a small, framed photograph. It wasn't of a wife or a child. It was a picture of a younger, prouder Marcus Thorne, his arm slung around an older man who shared his broad features, both of them grinning in front of a real, full-sized Thorne Haulage truck. His father. This was the legacy he had lost. She reached out an invisible hand, her fingers hovering just millimetres from the photograph, a profound, aching pity for this angry, broken man welling up inside her. He wasn't a monster. He was just another casualty, his grief curdled into a rage that was consuming him from the inside out.

It was then that she heard it. The unmistakable, terrifying sound of a key scraping against the outside of the lock. Her blood turned to ice. He was back. He must have forgotten something. Her mind raced, a frantic search for an exit, an escape route. But there was none. The flat was a small, one-bedroom box. There was no back door, no place to hide. The lock turned with a loud, final click. The door began to swing inwards. Ellie was trapped. Trapped in the chaotic, rage-filled epicentre of a volatile, unstable, and intermittently invisible man, with nowhere to run and no way of knowing if he could see her or not.
